title: 104_s2135
content: The Act titled "Coal Industry Retiree Health Equity Act" reduces contributions of eligible small assigned operators to the Coal Miners Combined Benefit Fund under section 9704A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The annual premium of an assigned operator under section 9704(a) is reduced for eligible small assigned operators, with the reduction not exceeding 5 percent of the operator's average annual taxable income for the preceding 5-taxable year period. The annual premiums for eligible small assigned operators are reduced by up to 5 percent of their average annual taxable income for the preceding 5-taxable year period. This reduction applies to plan years of the Combined Fund starting after January 31, 1993, and before October 1, 2003. Eligible small assigned operators are defined as assigned operators meeting specific criteria. An 'operator' meeting specific criteria, with average annual gross income not exceeding $25,000,000 for the 5-taxable year period before October 1, 1993, and not engaged in coal production for the current plan year. Production by a related person is considered production by the operator if they have employed employees in coal extraction. The section discusses the extraction and processing of coal for sale, with rules for determining gross income. It also sets a limit on annual premium reductions for the Combined Fund, not exceeding $5,000,000 per plan year. Eligible small assigned operators are exempt from certain premium reductions. The section discusses rules for determining gross income from coal sales and limits annual premium reductions for the Combined Fund. Eligible small assigned operators are exempt from certain premium reductions. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to plan years starting after January 31, 1993. In the case of an eligible small assigned operator, no penalty shall be imposed for failure to pay a premium installment before January 1, 1997, if paid before that date. Failure to pay due to reasonable cause, not willful neglect, can be corrected within 90 days of notice. The penalty for failure to pay a premium installment can be avoided if paid before January 1, 1997, or within 90 days of notice for reasonable cause, not willful neglect. SEC. 4. SUSPENSION OF CONTRIBUTIONS FOR CERTAIN ASSIGNED OPERATORS TO THE COMBINED FUND. Section 9704 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a one-time suspension of contributions for assigned operators when the net assets in the Combined Fund exceed 10 percent of benefits and costs. This suspension lasts for 24 months for operators not part of the 1988 agreement. The text discusses the suspension of contributions for assigned operators when the net assets in the Combined Fund exceed 10 percent of benefits and costs. This suspension lasts for 24 months for operators not part of the 1988 agreement. Additionally, a report to Congress on the operations of the Combined Fund is required within the first 12 months of the 24-month period. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding contributions for assigned operators in the Combined Fund. SEC. 5 amends the per beneficiary premium in the Internal Revenue Code to $2,116.67. SEC. 6 outlines disclosure requirements. Section 9704(h) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to provide information to the secretary and contributors of the Combined Fund. Trustees must make employment history information available to assigned operators upon request, with the option to charge reasonable fees. Additionally, section 9703(b)(2)(A) is amended to include specific provisions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a provision related to plan year without regard to any reduction under section 9704(e)(3)(B)(ii). SEC. 7. TREATMENT OF WITHDRAWAL LIABILITY. Withdrawal Liability amendment for 1988 agreement operators regarding payment to UMWA Benefit Plans under the Coal Industry Retiree Health Equity Act. The 1992 UMWA Benefit Plan exempts 1988 agreement operators from certain requirements and provides health benefits coverage to eligible beneficiaries. The 1992 UMWA Benefit Plan exempts 1988 agreement operators from premium assessments and instead charges the Combined Fund until a segregated sum is exhausted, after which premiums will be assessed against the operators. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include an exception in subsections (a) and (b)(2) of section 9711, stating that certain provisions do not apply as provided in subsection (g)(3).
